text: English grammar lesson 28 topic embedded
questions
part one this is a lesson in two parts
do you like getting packages in the mail
I love it
how big or how small a packages doesn't
matter what I like is the surprise I
want to know right away what's inside of
course sometimes I do know what's inside
because I'm the one who ordered it I
bought something online but even then
it's exciting it's fun because I want to
know if the product is any good I want
to find out if it's exactly what I
thought it would be now whether you know
it or not you've just heard several
examples of embedded questions do you
know what an embedded question is
embedded means placed inside an embedded
question is the question placed inside
another question or a question placed
inside a larger sentence if you're ready
let's get started with our lesson on
embedded question
here are three examples of embedded
questions which I said at the beginning
of my talk what I like is the surprise I
want to know what's inside I want to
know if the product is any good you see
the embedded questions placed inside
sentences larger statements and you'll
probably also notice that the embedded
question can have different positions
within a sentence why is that well we
need to talk about the uses of embedded
questions the functions
an embedded question is a type of noun
clause so it can have the same function
as a single word noun very often an
embedded question functions as the
direct object the object of a verb for
example I want to know what's inside I
want to know if the product is any good
these two embedded questions are direct
objects they're the objects of the verb
know we can also use an embedded
question as the subject of our sentence
for example what I like is the surprise
and note it takes a singular verb
let me test your understanding so far
here you see an embedded question as
part of a larger question do you want to
find out what's inside which of these
three answers is simply not possible
it's this last one remember an embedded
question does not ask a real question
it's based on a real question but the
actual question here is do you want to
find out or not
the important thing to remember about
embedded questions is that they are not
real questions that means they do not
use question word order remember there
is a difference between question word
order and statement word order
when we say a simple sentence we have a
subject and a verb when we ask questions
we invert the subject and verb we switch
places a verb comes first and then
there's a subject for example you ask
Jennifer where is the package here it is
you asked a real question where is the
package is verb the package subject verb
subject that's question word order you
wanted to know where the package was the
package subject was verb you wanted to
know where the package was where the
package was is an embedded question a
question inside a larger sentence
because it's not a real question I went
back to sentence word order statement
word order in which we have the subject
come first and a verb comes second
let's practice forming embedded
questions together here's a real
question what do I like to form the
embedded question we'll first place the
question word what then our subject I
and our verb like this is not a real
question so we no longer need the
helping verb do what I like is the
surprise it's the subject now of our
sentence look at the second real
question how much did someone spend
first we place our question word how
much our subject someone and our verb
now look this verb is in the past tense
we no longer need a helping verb but we
still need to show that this is a past
tense verb we use spent I don't need to
know how much someone spent now you know
how to form an embedded question but be
especially careful in three situations
first when the embedded question is
based on a yes/no question as in can we
open it now you don't see a question
where do you but we can form an embedded
question with the help of if let's ask
if we can open it now it's also possible
to use whether whether or not
let's ask whether we can open it now but
if is the more common choice especially
in everyday English we prefer whether or
whether or not when there are actually
two or more choices stated for example
let's ask whether we're going to open it
now or later also be careful when you
form an embedded question
based on a question about the subject
what is inside do you see in this real
question the question word what is
asking about the subject we already have
subject verb statement word order so no
changes need to be made I wonder what is
inside also be careful when you have a
question word a form of B and a noun or
noun phrase for example what is that
thing that thing is our subject so we're
going to place that before our form of B
what that thing is
that's the order we need so our complete
statement now is I can't understand what
that thing is the noun phrase comes
before is are you ready for an exercise
exercise one read the real question then
complete the new statement with an
embedded question let me help you with
number one the real question is what did
Jennifer order so to form the embedded
question identify your question word
your subject and the verb make sure it's
in the same verb tense
our new statement let's find out what
Jennifer ordered
number two
our new statement is do you know who the
package is for
three
our new statement I can't imagine what
she bought for her kids
for
our new statement I wonder if she can
put it together by herself
you could also use whether but the
choice of if is more common
five
our new question
can you guess what she is building
six
the new statement is can you tell me
what that is called in English do you
know the answer this is called a seesaw
an exercise one all of our embedded
questions functioned as objects of verbs
it's probably most common to use
embedded questions as direct objects
look at this list of common verbs
followed by embedded questions we have
asked find out guess no remember say C
and Wonder
it's very common to use embedded
questions after a verb to sound more
polite
we request information with verbs like
no tell and explain and by following
these verbs with an embedded question
our requests for information sound more
polite less demanding softer compared
for example the direct question where's
the bank with this less direct one can
you help me please I'd like to know
where the bank is compare this direct
question what time is it with this
indirect question sir could you please
tell me what time it is and compare this
direct question how do students register
with this more indirect one excuse me
ma'am could you please explain how
students register
[Music]
this is the end of part 1 before you go
on to part 2 please note that additional
practice is available at English cafe
comm follow the direct link listed in
the video description and then I'll see
you back here for part 2
